What's the best way to store leftover paint?

Here are some simple steps to keep your leftover paint usable for as long as possible:

1. Clean the can’s rim  
   • Wipe away any paint on the top edge and the lid.  
   • This ensures a tight seal and makes it easier to open next time.

2. Protect the paint surface  
   • For water-based (acrylic/latex) paints, press a piece of plastic cling-film directly onto the paint surface before closing the lid.  
   • That extra barrier helps prevent a skin from forming.

3. Seal the can tightly  
   • Replace the lid squarely and tap it down gently with a rubber mallet (or hammer plus a block of wood) until it sits flush.  
   • Avoid denting the lid or can, which can compromise the seal.

4. Reduce headspace (optional but very effective)  
   • Pour any excess paint into a smaller, airtight container (e.g. a mason jar) so there’s minimal air above the paint.  
   • Label the container with the paint name, brand, colour/mix code and date.

5. Store upright in a cool, dry place  
   • Ideal temperature: 10–25 °C, away from frost or heat sources.  
   • Keep out of direct sunlight and away from extreme temperature changes.  
   • Store on a level shelf in your garage, basement or utility closet.

6. Before reusing  
   • Stir or shake the paint thoroughly to reincorporate any settled pigments.  
   • Strain through a paint filter bag or old stocking if it’s become lumpy.

Following these steps will help your leftover paint stay fresh for months—or even years—so you can tackle touch-ups without having to buy a whole new can.

What's the best way to paint a room with high ceilings?

Here’s a step-by-step approach to painting a room with high ceilings safely and efficiently:

1. Gather the right tools and materials  
   • Paint (ceiling paint and wall paint of your chosen finish)  
   • Primer (if covering dark colors, stains or bare drywall)  
   • 9” roller frame + sleeves (nap length ½”–¾” depending on surface texture)  
   • Extension pole for your roller (telescoping poles typically extend 4–8 ft.)  
   • Angled sash brush (2–3″) for “cutting in” edges  
   • Drop cloths or heavy-duty plastic sheeting  
   • Painter’s tape (for moldings, windows, doors)  
   • Putty/patching compound and spackle knife  
   • Sandpaper (medium/fine grit)  
   • Ladder or a small mobile scaffold (or rent scaffolding for ceilings over 12 ft.)  
   • Paint tray, liners, stirring sticks, rags  

2. Prepare the room  
   • Remove or cover furniture and flooring. Lay drop cloths from wall to wall.  
   • Take down fixtures, switch plates, curtain rods.  
   • Use painter’s tape along moldings, window frames and doorframes.  
   • Fill nail holes or cracks with spackle. Once dry, sand smooth and wipe away dust.  
   • If walls are glossy or stained, wipe them with a mild detergent solution and rinse thoroughly before painting.  

3. Prime (if needed)  
   • Apply primer to bare drywall, patched areas or dark/stained walls.  
   • A quality primer ensures better adhesion and true paint color.  

4. “Cut in” the edges  
   • Start at the ceiling line and corners.  
   • Using your angled brush, paint a 2–3″ strip where the wall meets the ceiling, and along corners and trim.  
   • Keep a wet edge so your roller work will blend in seamlessly.  

5. Roll the main surfaces  
   • Attach the roller to your extension pole.  
   • Load the roller evenly in the tray—roll off excess paint on the ridged part of the tray.  
   • Working in 3–4 ft. sections, use a “W” or “M” pattern to distribute paint, then fill in without lifting the roller.  
   • Keep each section wet to avoid lap marks; overlap slightly onto the cut-in edges for a uniform finish.  

6. Tackle the ceiling (if painting it as well)  
   • Many pros paint the ceiling first for a crisp line against the walls, but if you’ve already cut in the walls you can roll the ceiling with a separate roller and pole.  
   • Use a thicker nap sleeve (¾″–1″) if your ceiling is textured.  

7. Apply additional coats  
   • Most walls need two coats for full coverage. Allow proper drying time—check manufacturer’s recommendations.  
   • Lightly sand between coats if you notice any drips or imperfections; wipe clean before recoating.  

8. Clean up and remove tape  
   • Remove painter’s tape while the paint is still slightly tacky for the cleanest edges.  
   • Clean brushes and rollers immediately according to paint type (water for latex, solvent for oil-based).  

9. Safety tips for high areas  
   • Use a sturdy ladder or mobile scaffold rated for your height requirement. Always follow load and height guidelines.  
   • If the ceiling is over 12 ft., consider renting a small scaffold or man-lift.  
   • Have someone “spot” your ladder, and never lean too far to one side—move the ladder as needed.  

With the right prep, equipment and technique, you’ll get professional-looking results even on very tall walls. If you need to rent scaffolding or want advice on sprayers and specialty rollers, stop by your local Zava DIY center—we’re happy to help!

How do I paint a bathtub?

Here’s a reliable step-by-step guide to refinishing (painting) a bathtub. You’ll need good ventilation, the right materials and some patience to get a durable, smooth finish.  

Materials & tools  
1. Protective gear: respirator or high-quality dust mask, safety glasses, nitrile gloves  
2. Cleaning supplies: heavy-duty bathroom cleaner or trisodium phosphate (TSP)  
3. Abrasives: 320–400-grit wet/dry sandpaper or sanding pads  
4. Vacuum with brush attachment or tack cloth  
5. Painter’s tape and plastic sheeting or drop cloths  
6. Bathtub refinishing kit (epoxy or acrylic‐enamel kit) which typically includes primer, topcoat, mixing cups and stirring sticks—alternatively, a single‐component epoxy spray designed for tubs  
7. Short-nap foam roller (if using brush/roller application) or HVLP spray gun (if spraying)  
8. Stir sticks, paint trays, mixing tools  

Step-by-step procedure  

1. Prepare the area  
   • Shut off ventilation fans, open any windows and lay down drop cloths outside the tub.  
   • Remove soap dishes, shower heads, faucets or any loose hardware that will get in the way.  
   • Mask off tile, walls, fixtures and overflow/drain openings tightly with painter’s tape and plastic sheeting.  

2. Deep clean the tub surface  
   • Spray the entire surface with a heavy-duty bathroom cleaner or a TSP solution.  
   • Scrub thoroughly to remove soap scum, body oils, mildew and any wax or silicone residue.  
   • Rinse and wipe dry. Any residue left behind will interfere with adhesion.  

3. Sand for adhesion  
   • Using 320–400-grit wet/dry sandpaper or a dedicated sanding pad, sand the entire tub surface to dull the original finish.  
   • Focus on glossy areas until they’re uniformly matte—this gives the primer something to grip.  
   • Wipe away dust with a vacuum brush attachment or tack cloth, then wipe with a clean, damp lint-free cloth. Let dry completely.  

4. Final surface prep  
   • Inspect for chips or cracks. Fill any small pits or cracks with a two-part tub putty or epoxy filler, following the manufacturer’s instructions.  
   • Sand the patched areas smooth, then remove dust again.  

5. Mix the refinishing primer/topcoat  
   • Follow the refinishing-kit instructions exactly—measure and mix the resin and hardener in the correct ratios.  
   • Stir thoroughly but gently to avoid trapping air bubbles.  

6. Apply the primer or base coat  
   • If you’re using a two-coat system, the first coat is usually a bonding or primer layer.  
   • Apply with a foam roller (or spray) in overlapping strokes. Keep a wet edge to avoid lap marks.  
   • Allow to flash off the recommended time (usually 30–60 minutes).  

7. Apply the topcoat  
   • Mix and apply the finish coat just like you did the primer.  
   • Work quickly and methodically: start at the high points and roll downward so drips land on uncoated areas.  
   • If spraying, maintain a consistent distance (6–8 inches) and overlap each pass by about 50%.  

8. Inspect and touch up  
   • After the first topcoat dries (check kit for dry time—usually 2–4 hours), inspect under good light.  
   • Lightly sand any runs or orange-peel texture with 600-grit wet/dry sandpaper, then wipe clean.  
   • Apply a second (and if recommended, a third) topcoat for full coverage and uniform gloss.  

9. Cure time  
   • Close off the area, keep it ventilated, and do not use the tub for the full cure period—typically 48–72 hours or as specified by your kit.  
   • Avoid setting heavy objects on the surface or cleaning with harsh chemicals during curing.  

10. Reassemble and maintain  
   • Remove all masking tape and plastic. Reinstall hardware and fixtures.  
   • For regular cleaning, use nonabrasive cleaners and a soft sponge to prolong the finish.  

Tips & reminders  
• Always read and follow all safety and technical instructions on your refinishing-kit labels.  
• Temperature and humidity affect drying times—ideal conditions are 15–25 °C (60–77 °F) and moderate humidity.  
• If you’re not comfortable spraying or mixing two-part resins, consider hiring a professional refinisher—DIY kits can be tricky.  

With careful prep, proper products and patience, you can give your bathtub a like-new finish at a fraction of the cost of replacement. Good luck!

What paint trays are easiest to clean up?

Here are the main tray options ranked by how little cleanup they require:  

1. Disposable Tray Liners  
   • Description: Thin plastic or paper “sleeves” that sit inside a standard plastic tray.  
   • Cleanup: When you’re done painting, simply pull out the liner and toss it. The tray beneath stays clean.  
   • Best for: One-off jobs or infrequently used trays.  

2. Silicone (Non-Stick) Trays  
   • Description: Flexible, non-stick silicone molds in the shape of a paint tray.  
   • Cleanup: Once the paint has dried you can peel it off in sheets—no scrubbing. Rinse out any wet paint with water or the appropriate solvent.  
   • Best for: Hobbyists and small interior jobs; portable and very durable.  

3. Plastic Reusable Trays with Smooth Finish  
   • Description: Rigid polypropylene or ABS trays with a slick, non-porous surface.  
   • Cleanup: While not disposable, paint beads up and wipes off more easily than rougher plastics. For water-based paint: rinse under warm water and use a soft brush or sponge. For oil-based: a light solvent wash.  
   • Best for: Regular painters who want a balance of durability and relatively easy cleaning.  

4. Metal Trays with Non-Stick Coating  
   • Description: Steel or aluminum trays coated internally with a non-stick finish.  
   • Cleanup: Coating prevents paint from bonding tightly. Wipe out wet paint or, for dried spots, use a plastic scraper and mild solvent.  
   • Best for: Professional or heavy-duty use—more rugged but a bit heavier and pricier.  

Tips for Even Easier Cleanup:  
- Always remove excess paint back into the can before cleaning the tray.  
- For water-based (emulsion or acrylic) paint, clean immediately with warm soapy water.  
- For oil-based paint, use mineral spirits or the manufacturer’s recommended solvent.  
- Keep a small bucket of warm, soapy water nearby to rinse brushes and trays as you go.  

If you’re after absolute minimal fuss, go with a standard reusable tray plus a pack of disposable liners. You get the sturdiness of a hard tray and the simplicity of “liner pulls, liner tosses.”

What's the best way to paint a concrete porch?

Here’s a reliable step-by-step method for painting a concrete porch so that the paint sticks well and lasts:

1. Gather materials and tools  
   • Concrete cleaner or degreaser (or trisodium phosphate—TSP—alternative)  
   • Stiff bristle brush or push broom  
   • Garden hose or pressure washer  
   • Concrete‐etching solution (if your porch is very smooth)  
   • Concrete patching compound for cracks and spalls  
   • Masonry primer or concrete floor primer (acrylic‐latex or epoxy‐based)  
   • Porch or concrete‐floor paint (acrylic‐latex or epoxy floor paint)  
   • Non-slip additive (optional, for traction)  
   • Paint roller with medium nap, roller frame and extension pole  
   • Angled paintbrush for edges and corners  
   • Painter’s tape and plastic sheeting  
   • Protective gear: gloves, goggles, dust mask or respirator  

2. Choose the right weather window  
   • Temperature between 50°F and 85°F (10°C–30°C)  
   • Low humidity (<70 %) and no rain in the forecast for at least 48 hours  

3. Clean thoroughly  
   a. Clear the porch of furniture, planters, mats, etc.  
   b. Sweep away loose dirt and debris.  
   c. Apply a concrete cleaner or degreaser according to label instructions.  
   d. Scrub with a stiff‐bristle brush or push broom.  
   e. Rinse completely with a garden hose or pressure washer.  
   f. Allow to dry 24 hours or until surface is bone-dry.  

4. Etch the surface (if necessary)  
   • If the concrete is very smooth, use a mild acid etching solution (typically muriatic acid diluted per instructions) or a commercial concrete etcher.  
   • Scrub it on, wait the recommended time, then rinse thoroughly.  
   • Let the slab dry fully (24–48 hours) before proceeding.  

5. Repair cracks and surface damage  
   • Fill cracks or spalls with a concrete patching compound or filler designed for horizontal surfaces.  
   • Smooth with a trowel and let cure per manufacturer’s directions.  
   • Lightly sand any high spots once the patch is cured, and clean away dust.  

6. Mask off and protect adjacent areas  
   • Use painter’s tape along walls, door thresholds, and any fixtures.  
   • Lay down plastic sheeting or drop cloths if paint might splash.  

7. Apply primer  
   • Stir the primer thoroughly.  
   • Using a roller, apply a thin, even coat across the entire porch surface.  
   • Cut in edges and corners with an angled brush.  
   • Allow primer to dry per label instructions (usually 4–6 hours).  

8. Add non-slip traction (optional)  
   • If desired, broadcast non-slip additive into the wet primer or mix it directly into the paint.  

9. Paint the porch  
   a. Stir the porch/concrete‐floor paint well.  
   b. Using a roller, apply the first coat evenly, maintaining a wet edge.  
   c. Cut in along edges with the brush.  
   d. Let the first coat dry fully (typically 4–8 hours).  
   e. Apply a second coat for uniform coverage and durability.  

10. Cure and re-open to traffic  
   • Keep foot traffic off the surface for at least 24 hours after the final coat (follow paint manufacturer’s cure time—it may be 48–72 hours for full hardness).  
   • Return furniture and planters only after the paint is fully cured.  

Tips for best results  
- Always follow temperature and humidity guidelines on the product labels.  
- Use paint and primer from the same manufacturer when possible—they’re formulated to work together.  
- Regularly sweep and hose off the porch to prolong the finish.  

By thoroughly cleaning, properly preparing, and using quality primer and floor paint, your concrete porch will look great and stand up to weather and foot traffic for years to come.

How do I paint over a dark red wall?

Here’s a straightforward, step-by-step approach to covering a dark red wall with a lighter or neutral color:

1. Gather your tools and materials  
   • Drop cloths or old sheets  
   • Painter’s tape  
   • Mild detergent or trisodium phosphate (TSP) cleaner  
   • Sponge or soft cloth  
   • Medium-grit sandpaper (120–150)  
   • Spackle (for filling holes) and putty knife  
   • Stain-blocking or red-blocking primer (water-based or oil-based)  
   • Primer tint (optional, tinted toward your new topcoat color)  
   • Quality interior paint (two coats)  
   • Paint tray, rollers (medium nap), angled sash brush  

2. Prepare the surface  
   a. Remove outlet covers, switch plates, and any wall hangings.  
   b. Lay down drop cloths and tape off trim, windows, ceiling lines.  
   c. Wash the wall with a mild detergent solution (or TSP) to remove dirt, grease, and chalky residues. Rinse and let fully dry.  
   d. Lightly sand glossy areas so primer and paint adhere better. Wipe away dust with a damp cloth.  
   e. Fill nail holes or cracks with spackle, smooth with a putty knife, let dry, then sand flush.

3. Prime with a stain-blocking, red-blocking primer  
   • Choose a primer labeled for “high-hide” or “stain blocking” (brands like Zinsser BIN, KILZ Premium, etc.).  
   • If you’re going from very dark red to white or pale pastels, tint the primer slightly toward your final shade—this can reduce the number of topcoats.  
   • Apply one even coat of primer with a roller; cut in around edges with a brush.  
   • Allow primer to dry fully (per manufacturer’s instructions).

4. Apply your topcoat paint  
   • Stir your paint thoroughly and pour into a clean tray.  
   • Cut in along ceilings, trim, and corners with the sash brush.  
   • Roll on the first coat of paint in a “W” or “M” pattern for even coverage, then fill in.  
   • Let the first coat dry completely.  
   • Inspect for any remaining red bleed or uneven spots—lightly spot-prime if needed.  
   • Apply a second full coat of paint.  

5. Finish up  
   • Remove painter’s tape while the last coat is still slightly wet for crisp lines.  
   • Reinstall outlet covers and switch plates.  
   • Clean brushes and rollers per the paint manufacturer’s recommendations.  
   • Enjoy your freshly transformed wall!

Tips:  
• Work in a well-ventilated space and maintain a comfortable temperature (ideally 10–30 °C).  
• Use a high-quality roller cover (10–12 mm nap) for smooth walls to avoid stipple.  
• If you’re going very light (white, off-white) over deep red, an oil-based primer can give extra confidence against bleed-through—but modern acrylic stain-blockers do a great job, too.

How do I paint interior doors?

Here’s a step-by-step guide to getting smooth, durable results when painting interior doors:

1. Gather tools & materials  
   • High-quality interior primer (adhesion primer or stain-blocking if you have knots, tannins or stains)  
   • Interior door paint in semi-gloss or satin (acrylic enamel or water-based alkyd)  
   • Medium-bristle sash brush (2–2½″) plus small trim brush for cracks  
   • 4 mm–6 mm microfiber roller or small foam roller for flat panels  
   • Sandpaper (120-grit and 220-grit) or sanding block  
   • Wood filler or spackling compound  
   • Degreaser or trisodium phosphate (TSP) cleaner  
   • Clean rags, tack cloth  
   • Painter’s tape  
   • Drop cloths or cardboard to protect floor  
   • Screwdriver or drill with bit to remove hardware   
   • Paint tray or disposable liners  

2. Remove door hardware  
   • Unscrew hinges if you plan to paint doors flat (highly recommended for best finish).  
   • Remove doorknobs, locks, strike plates.  
   • Label hinges and screws so re-installation is quick and correct.  

3. Clean & degrease  
   • Wash both sides of the door with a degreaser or diluted TSP.  
   • Rinse with clean water and let the door dry completely.  

4. Repair & sand  
   • Fill nail holes, scratches or gouges with wood filler or spackling.  
   • Once the filler is set, sand flat with 120-grit.  
   • Lightly sand the entire door with 220-grit to scuff the old finish and ensure better adhesion.  
   • Wipe away all dust with a tack cloth or damp rag.  

5. Mask & set up  
   • Lay the door on two sawhorses or a workbench with padding.  
   • Place drop cloths under.  
   • Apply painter’s tape to any glass, hinges, or areas you don’t want painted.  

6. Prime (if needed)  
   • Apply one coat of primer to all surfaces (stiles, rails, panels, edges).  
   • Use your sash brush for grooves and the roller for flat areas.  
   • Let primer dry fully according to manufacturer instructions.  
   • Lightly sand with 220-grit, then remove dust.  

7. First coat of finish paint  
   • Stir paint gently—no shaking.  
   • Cut in grooves and edges with a brush. Roll the panels and flats with smooth, even strokes.  
   • Brush strokes should follow the grain. Roll in one direction, then “tip off” (very lightly roll over to smooth).  
   • Allow recommended drying time (usually 2–4 hours for water-based paints).  

8. Sand & second coat  
   • Lightly sand with 220-grit or fine sanding pad to knock down any raised grain or dust nibs.  
   • Clean off dust with tack cloth.  
   • Apply the second (finish) coat exactly as before. Two thin coats are better than one thick coat.  

9. Cure & reassemble  
   • Let the door dry and cure for at least 24 hours (follow paint label).  
   • Remove tape, re-attach hinges and hardware.  
   • Rehang the door, making any hinge-pin or latch adjustments if needed.  

Tips & best practices  
   – Paint in a well-ventilated, dust-free space at 10–25 °C for optimal drying.  
   – Avoid painting on very humid or cold days.  
   – Use a dedicated door-painting rack if you have multiple doors—this speeds up workflow.  
   – Keep your brush wet between coats by wrapping it lightly in plastic.  
   – Clean brushes/rollers immediately after use to prolong their life.  

Following these steps will help you achieve professional-looking, durable results on your interior doors. Good luck with your project!

What's the best way to paint glass?

Here’s a reliable, step-by-step approach to getting good, long-lasting results when painting glass:

1. Choose the right paint  
   • Glass‐specific paints or enamels (water-based or solvent-based)  
   • Spray paints labeled for glass or “all-surface” use  
   • Acrylic glass paints (often require heat-curing)

2. Gather supplies  
   • Degreasing cleaner or isopropyl alcohol  
   • Lint-free cloths  
   • Fine-grit sandpaper (220–320 grit) or Scotch-Brite pad  
   • Glass primer or adhesion promoter  
   • Paint (brush-on or spray)  
   • Optional: painter’s tape, stencils, rubber gloves, drop cloth

3. Prep the surface  
   a. Clean thoroughly: remove oils, dust, fingerprints with glass cleaner or alcohol.  
   b. Dry completely.  
   c. Lightly scuff the area to be painted with fine sandpaper or a Scotch-Brite pad.  
   d. Wipe again to remove all sanding dust.

4. Apply primer/adhesion promoter  
   • Follow manufacturer’s instructions (spray or brush-on).  
   • Allow to flash-off or dry per label (usually 10–30 minutes).

5. Paint  
   a. If using spray: shake well, keep can 25–30 cm from surface, apply 2–3 light coats.  
   b. If using brush-on: use a soft brush, apply thin, even coats; avoid drips.  
   c. Let each coat dry fully before adding the next (check your paint’s instructions).

6. Curing  
   • Air-dry paints: typically 24 hours to full hardness.  
   • Heat-set enamels or speciality glass paints: you may need to bake in an oven (follow paint label—for example, 30 minutes at 120 °C).  
   • Avoid washing or heavy use until fully cured.

7. (Optional) Seal  
   • A clear acrylic or polyurethane varnish adds durability, especially on frequently handled items.

8. Tips for a great finish  
   • Work in a dust-free, well-ventilated area.  
   • Use painter’s tape or stencils for clean edges or patterns.  
   • Test on a scrap piece of glass first.  
   • Wear gloves to avoid fingerprints on your freshly painted surface.

With good prep, the right primer/paint combo, and proper curing, your painted glass will look professional and stand up to everyday use.

How do I prevent brush bristles from falling out while painting?

Here are some tried-and-tested tips to keep loose bristles at bay when you paint:

1. Start with a quality brush  
   • Cheap brushes often shed more. Look for ones labeled “for enamel,” “for acrylic,” or “for professional use.”  
   • Synthetic filaments (nylon, polyester) tend to shed less than natural-hair brushes.

2. “Pre-condition” a new brush  
   • Rinse it gently in warm soapy water (or the appropriate solvent) to remove manufacturing debris.  
   • Comb through the hairs with your fingers to pull out any loose bristles before you ever dip it in paint.

3. Soak and comb  
   • If you still spot stray hairs, soak the bristles in warm water (or brush cleaner) for a few minutes.  
   • Use your fingers or a fine-tooth comb to sweep out any remaining loose fibers.

4. Pinch the ferrule (metal band)  
   • Sometimes the ferrule isn’t crimped tight enough, so the hairs aren’t held firmly.  
   • Gently squeeze the sides of the ferrule with needle-nose pliers—just enough to snug it up around the bristles, without crushing them.

5. Load the brush correctly  
   • Don’t dip more than about one-third of the bristle length into the paint.  
   • Overloading stresses the base of the bristles and can pull loose fibers out.

6. Use smooth strokes, not scrubbing  
   • Drag the brush tip along the surface instead of scrubbing or force-spreading paint; harsh back-and-forth movement dislodges bristles.

7. Clean and store with care  
   • After painting, clean thoroughly with the proper solvent or soap & water, working from the ferrule out to the tip.  
   • Wrap the bristles in paper or a protective sleeve and store brushes flat or with bristles pointing up to avoid bending and splaying.

8. Optional: Brush conditioners and stiffeners  
   • You can find brush-conditioning products or even mild hair conditioner to restore flexibility and help bind the filaments together.  
   • Apply a small dab, rinse lightly, and reshape.

By starting with a good brush, removing loose hairs up front, loading it properly, and treating it gently, you’ll dramatically reduce—or even eliminate—those frustrating stray bristles in your finish. Happy painting!

What's the best way to paint over mildew-resistant paint?

Here’s a reliable, step-by-step approach to repainting over an existing mildew-resistant (anti‐mold) coating. Even though those paints discourage mold growth, they still need proper prep so your new finish will look great and stick well.

1. Inspect and clean  
   • Look for any loose, peeling paint or active mildew spots.  
   • If you spot mildew, kill it first:  
     – Mix one part bleach (or a mildew remover) to three parts water.  
     – Wear gloves and eye protection.  
     – Sponge on, scrub gently with a soft brush, then rinse thoroughly with clean water.  
     – Allow walls to dry completely (24 – 48 hours ideally).

2. Repair any damage  
   • Scrape away any flaking paint with a scraper.  
   • Fill cracks or small holes with a suitable filler or spackle.  
   • Once the filler is dry, sand smooth and wipe away the dust.

3. Lightly sand the entire surface  
   • Use 120–150 grit sandpaper or a sanding sponge to scuff-up glossy or smooth areas.  
   • This “tooth” helps your new paint adhere.  
   • Wipe away sanding dust with a slightly damp cloth or tack cloth, then let dry.

4. Prime if needed  
   You may be able to skip a full prime coat if:  
     – You’re using the same type of paint (latex over latex)  
     – You’re repainting with a very similar color and sheen  
   Otherwise, or if the old paint is very glossy or oil-based, use a good bonding/stain-blocking primer.  
   Recommended primers:  
     – Zinsser Bulls Eye 1-2-3 (water-based, adheres to glossy or oil paint)  
     – Zinsser BIN (shellac-based, for tough stains or high humidity areas)

5. Choose your topcoat  
   • Pick a quality interior latex paint formulated for bathrooms or kitchens if moisture is a concern. Those often carry an anti-mildew additive.  
   • Flat or matte sheens hide imperfections; eggshell or satin are easier to clean.

6. Paint application  
   • Stir your paint well and pour into a clean tray.  
   • Use a good-quality brush for cutting in around trim, then a roller (¾" nap for walls) for the field.  
   • Apply two even coats, allowing the first coat to fully dry (check can for recoat time) before the second.

7. Drying and ventilation  
   • Keep windows or exhaust fans on to help curing and to discourage future mold growth.  
   • Avoid showering or heavy humidity for at least 24 hours after finishing.

By thoroughly cleaning, repairing, sanding and—where appropriate—priming, you’ll ensure your new paint layer bonds well and stays mildew-free longer. Good luck with your project!

How long should polyurethane dry between coats?

Here are some general guidelines for drying times between coats—always check the label on your specific product for exact times:

1. Water-based polyurethane  
   • Dry to the touch: 1–2 hours at 20 °C (68 °F), 50 % RH  
   • Lightly scuff-sand and recoat: 2–4 hours  
   • Maximum recoat window: ideally within 24 hours (after that, tack down dust before recoating)

2. Oil-based polyurethane  
   • Dry to the touch: 6–8 hours at 20 °C (68 °F), 50 % RH  
   • Lightly scuff-sand and recoat: 8–24 hours (overnight is common)  
   • Some trim/fast-dry formulas may allow recoat in as little as 6 hours—check the can

3. Tips for best results  
   • Temperature & humidity matter: cooler or more humid conditions slow curing—allow extra time.  
   • Always lightly scuff-sand between coats (220–320 grit), then remove dust thoroughly.  
   • Stir (don’t shake) your poly to avoid bubbles, and apply thin, even coats.  
   • Follow the manufacturer’s full instructions on the tin for final cure time before heavy use.

By sticking to these guidelines you’ll get a durable, smooth finish with no tackiness or dust nibs between coats.

What's the most durable paint tray?

When it comes to longevity under heavy-use conditions, metal paint trays—especially those made from heavy-gauge, e-coated or stainless steel—tend to outlast plastic ones by a wide margin. Here are your best options:

1. Heavy-Gauge Steel Trays  
   • Material: Cold-rolled steel with a corrosion-resistant e-coat finish  
   • Pros: Won’t warp under heat or solvents, easy to clean, stands up to rough handling  
   • Cons: Slightly heavier; if the coating is nicked, bare steel can rust  

2. Stainless-Steel Trays  
   • Material: 304 or 316 stainless steel  
   • Pros: Inherently rustproof, very sturdy, dishwasher-safe for cleanup  
   • Cons: Highest price point  

3. Aluminum Trays with Nonstick Finish  
   • Material: Cast or stamped aluminium with a Teflon-style coating  
   • Pros: Lightweight, corrosion-resistant, paint releases easily  
   • Cons: Coating can wear off over time if you scrub aggressively  

4. Reinforced Plastic (High-Density Polyethylene)  
   • Material: Thick, solvent-resistant HDPE  
   • Pros: Inexpensive, drop-resistant, chemical-resistant (solvent-based paints)  
   • Cons: Will eventually flex or crack after heavy use  

Top Picks for Durability  
– Linzer ProSlope Stainless Steel Paint Tray (rustproof, lifetime guarantee)  
– Wooster Sherlock Heavy-Gauge Steel Tray (e-coated, extra-deep well)  
– Wagner FlexTray II Aluminum with nonstick coating  
– Buckeye High-Density Polyethylene Tray (budget-friendly, chemical-resistant)

Recommendation  
If budget allows and you want truly “set it in your toolbox forever” performance, go with the Linzer stainless-steel tray. If you need a balance of cost and ruggedness, the e-coated Wooster steel tray is a very popular choice.
